ASIA-PAC

PBoC's Governor Yi Gang said monetary policy should be relatively loose as China's economy is under pressure, but also stressed it cannot be too loose. (Newswires)

US President Trump said if China's economy is in trouble, it is because of his policies, but also stated that he has a great respect for China's Xi. (Fox News/Newswires)

US Commerce Secretary Ross said the US and China are having frequent conversations and that US President Trump has not committed to intervening in the Huawei case. Elsewhere, there were reports that US and China trade teams are to reconvene sometime after January 1st, while US Agriculture Secretary Perdue said he is hopeful China will buy more US soybeans and the latest purchases were "promising”. (Newswires)

China is to suspend the release of some economic data, potentially causing speculation about the reliability of economic readings. (Nikkei)
 

UK

UK PM May suggested instead of an expiry date to the backstop, a commencement date for the future relationship to EU27 leaders at the summit. (Sky News)

There were initial comments from UK Government spokesperson that the parliament vote on the Brexit deal is still possible next week, although this was later followed by reports that UK PM May spokesman said the meaningful vote on Brexit will not happen before Christmas but will happen as soon as possible next month before January 21st. (Newswires)

EU said to consider a backstop declaration with legal force and said to consider aspirational end-date for the backstop, while the EU is also said to expect another Brexit summit in January. (Newswires)


EU

EU ECB Lending Rate (Dec) 0.25% vs. Exp. 0.25% (Prev. 0.25%). (Newswires)
EU ECB Refinancing Rate Dec 0.00% vs. Exp. 0.00% (Prev. 0.00%)
EU ECB Deposit Rate Dec -0.40% vs. Exp. -0.4% (Prev. -0.4%)

ECB kept all key rates on hold as expected and reiterated rates to remain at their present levels at least through the summer of 2019, while the ECB confirmed asset purchases will conclude at the end of 2018 and enhanced forward guidance on reinvestments. (Newswires)

Governing Council is enhancing its forward guidance on reinvestment in which it intends to continue reinvesting, in full, the principal payments from maturing securities purchased under the APP for an extended period of time past the date when it starts raising the key ECB interest rates, and in any case for as long as necessary to maintain favourable liquidity conditions.

ECB's Draghi said timing of a rate hike and specific timeframe for the 'extended period' language was not discussed in meeting, while LTROs were mentioned but not in detail. Draghi also said trade situation is probably better than two months ago and that although some EM vulnerabilities are less urgent than two months ago, the atmosphere is characterised by increased general uncertainty. Furthermore, Draghi noted that risks to growth are still broadly balanced, but balance of risks is moving to the downside.

ECB policy-makers debated changing the balance of the risk assessment to highlight downside risk, according to sources. (Newswires)

EU's Moscovici said Italy has made a "significant effort" on its budget and that the meeting with Italy's Economy Minister Tria was "very constructive". Furthermore, he said that work is continuing to quickly reach a compromise on the budget, while it was separately reported that Italy Finance Minister Tria is to stay in Brussels till the budget deal is reached. (Newswires/ANSA)

Reports suggested French no-confidence vote was rejected. (Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES

Saudi Arabia was said to target US with a large oil export cut in which the cut is aimed at reducing their visible stockpiles, while reports suggested that Saudi crude shipments to the US next month could test the 30-year low set in 2017 of 582,000 BPD which would be down 40% from the most recent 3-month average. (Newswires)

Iran's Oil Minister Zangeneh said we have no plan to reduce oil output. (IRNA)

IEA Monthly Report stated that global oil demand growth estimate for 2018 and 2019 is maintained at 1.3mln BPD and 1.4mln BPD respectively. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICAL

US Senate has passed second resolution saying Saudi Crown Prince MBS is responsible for murder of journalist Khashoggi, while the US Senate also voted to withdraw military support for Saudi-led coalition in Yemen. (Newswires/FT)
 

US

Federal prosecutors are investigating whether US President Trump's inaugural committee misspent some of the record amount of funds it raised. (WSJ)

US President Trump is to hold a hearing on Friday on the proposed US-EU trade deal. (Newswires)

US Secretary of State Pompeo and Canadian Foreign Minister Freeland are to hold talks on Friday, according to the State Department. (Newswires)

US Import Prices MM Nov -1.6% vs. Exp. -0.9% (Prev. 0.5%)


MARKET RECAP

General Electric (GE) surged today after long time bear JPMorgan upgraded the stock. Aflac (AFL) outperformed following reports it was in talks with a Japanese co. looking to take a stake in the insurance provider. Proctor & Gamble (PG) traded higher on the back of an upgrade at BOAML. Macerich (MAC) was uplifted in earlier trade by reports of Simon Property (SPG) interested in bidding for the co. but pared back some of the gains later on after Simon Property denied the claims. Caterpillar (CAT) made gains on the open after reporting strong global sales in November. Apple (AAPL) gave upward pressure to indices today where it announced the development of a new campus in Austin, Texas. CVS (CVS) weighed down the healthcare sector as a US District judge is expected to block its merger with Aetna (AET). Under Armour (UAA) underperformed after it provided 2019 revenue growth forecasts below estimates. SPX -0.03% at 2650, NDX +0.06% at 6768, DJI +0.28% at 24597.

Treasuries traded choppy on Thursday and ended the session mixed with the only major catalyst being the ECB decision leaving interest rates unchanged; yields fell by 1-2bps after ECB’s Draghi press conference initially moving in tandem with bunds; longer dated yields then edged higher following upticks equities. Most of the action was concentrated at the extremes of the curve with shorter dated yields lower by c.1bps and longer dated yields higher by c.1bps a settlement. The US Treasury sold USD 16bln in 30yr bonds stopping through by 0.2bps at a high yield of 3.165%, the lowest since September. The bid-to-cover came in at 2.31 and indicated an overall strong demand for the auction. In terms of the breakdown, directs secured a portion above recent averages and indirects were awarded the largest share since January with dealers left with the smallest portion since January. US T-note futures (Z8) settled unchanged at 129-09.

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 13th December: ECB ends asset purchases
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.
 

US MARKET WRAP – 13th December: ECB ends asset purchases

* SNAP-SHOT: Equities mixed, treasuries flat, dollar flat, crude up.

* REAR-VIEW: EU Summit kicks off, EU to consider aspirational end-date for backstop, EU upbeat on Italy’s budget negotiations, Trump says China’s weakness caused by his polices.

* AHEAD: Chinese Industrial Output & Retail Sales German, French and Eurozone Flash PMI's, Russian Central Bank Key Rate Decision, US Retail Sales and Industrial Production, ECB's de Guindos, Nowotny and Lautenschlager Speaking

** Note: The desk will be closing at 18:00 GMT; following the Baker Hughes Release **

 

* ECB: As expected, the ECB stood pat on rates and confirmed the conclusion of their APP, whilst maintaining their guidance on rates. Alongside the policy statement, the Bank enhanced their forward guidance by noting that “the Governing Council intends to continue reinvesting, in full, the principal payments from maturing securities purchased under the APP for an extended period of time past the date when it starts raising the key ECB interest rates”. During his press conference, ECB President Draghi noted that incoming information has been weaker than expected, whilst the latest data and surveys were weaker than expected, thus suggesting slower growth momentum ahead. This sentiment was reflected in the staff economic projections which saw 2018 growth lowered to 1.9% from 2.0% and 2019 cut to 1.7% from 1.8%. On the inflation front, forecasters upgraded, 2018 HICP to 1.8% from 1.7%, whilst 2019 was lowered to 1.7% from 1.8%. Arguably the main source of market reaction from the press conference emanated from the Bank’s assessment of risks surrounding he Euro Area economy with policymakers sticking to their current ‘broadly balanced’ view, whilst acknowledging that risks were now moving to the downside. Later, ECB sources reported that ECB policy-makers debated changing the balance of the risk assessment to highlight downside risk;

* TRADE: US President Trump stated that if China's economy is in trouble, it is because of his policies adding he has a great respect for Chinese President Xi. There were reports suggesting US and China trade teams are to reconvene sometime after  January 1st while the Chinese Commerce Ministry announced that they welcome a US trade delegation to visit China. In related comments, US Commerce Secretary Ross noted that the US and China are having frequent conversations and that Trump has not committed to intervening in the Huawei case. US Trade Advisor Navarro noted that China is buying soybeans and stated that investors should now focus on March when a China offer is due; he also appeared confident that the USMCA will reach the Congressional floor. Elsewhere, US President Trump is to hold a hearing on Friday on the proposed US-EU trade deal.

* BREXIT: Thursday saw a number of responses to yesterday’s confidence vote which was a victory for PM May. Focus shifted on the EU Summit where many European leaders vowed support for the British PM. Particular attention fell on comments from Irish PM Varadkar who claimed that the EU could provide a greater assurance to the UK that a future trade agreement could be negotiated quickly in order to avoid the backstop coming into effect. Also, Dutch PM Rutte urged the EU to do everything to help May though warning that room for manoeuvre is limited while Austrian Chancellor Kurz stands ready to accommodate requests if the solutions are approved by a majority in both EU and UK parliaments. There were also rumours over a special Brexit-EU summit in January. With regards to internal political developments, a UK PM May spokesman confirmed that the meaningful vote on Brexit will not happen before Christmas but will happen as soon as possible in January, before the 21st. In later news, the EU said to consider a backstop declaration with legal forces well as an aspirational end-date for the backstop.

* ITALY: EU's Moscovici was upbeat on progress made in budget negotiations with the country; he noted that Italy a "significant effort" and added that the meeting with Italy's Economy Minister Tria on Thursday was "very constructive". He announced that work is continuing to quickly reach a compromise and stressed he does not want to open disciplinary action against the country.

* WTI (F9) SETTLES USD 1.43 HIGHER AT USD 52.58/BBL, BRENT (F9) SETTLES USD 1.30 HIGHER AT USD 61.45/BBL. Oil traded higher on Thursday, with traders debating whether moves undertaken by OPEC last week can support a recovery in prices. Analysts at UBS have continued to talk up the potential for crude to rise in the near-term, noting that the extreme sell-off in the last two months leaves oil poised for a recovery as underlying positive fundamentals come back into focus. Specifically looking at Thursday's price action, Citi said "The International Energy Agency monthly report provided another viewpoint, with its 415k bpd downward revision to non-OPEC supply for 2019 raising its projected call on OPEC crude oil to 31.7mln bpd. The IEA also highlighted the possibility of unplanned outages resulting in a deeper drop in OPEC supply, with Iran and Venezuela topping the list of members at risk."

 SPX -0.03% at 2650, NDX +0.06% at 6768, DJI +0.28% at 24597. SECTORS: Energy +0.33%, Materials -1.15%, Industrials -0.26%, Cons Discretionary -0.44%, Cons Staples +0.68%, Healthcare +0.07%, Financials -0.61%, Tech +0.19%, Telecoms -0.19%, Utilities +0.88%.

*STOCK SPECIFICS: General Electric (GE) surged today after long time bear JPMorgan upgraded the stock. Aflac (AFL) outperformed following reports it was in talks with a Japanese co. looking to take a stake in the insurance provider. Proctor & Gamble (PG) traded higher on the back of an upgrade at BOAML. Macerich (MAC) was uplifted in earlier trade by reports of Simon Property (SPG) interested in bidding for the co. but pared back some of the gains later on after Simon Property denied the claims. Caterpillar (CAT) made gains on the open after reporting strong global sales in November. Apple (AAPL) gave upward pressure to indices today where it announced the development of a new campus in Austin, Texas. CVS (CVS) weighed down the healthcare sector as a US District judge is expected to block its merger with Aetna (AET). Under Armour (UAA) underperformed after it provided 2019 revenue growth forecasts below estimates.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z8) SETTLE UNCHANGHED AT 129-09. Treasuries traded choppy on Thursday and ended  the session mixed with the only major catalyst being the ECB decision leaving interest rates unchanged; yields fell by 1-2bps after ECB’s Draghi press conference initially moving in tandem with bunds;  longer dated yields then edged higher following upticks equities. Most of the action was concentrated at the extremes of the curve with shorter dated yields lower by c.1bps and longer dated yields higher by c.1bps a settlement. The US Treasury sold USD 16bln in 30yr bonds stopping through by 0.2bps at a high yield of 3.165%, the lowest since September. The bid-to-cover came in at 2.31 and indicated an overall strong demand for the auction. Looking at the breakdown, directs secured a portion above recent averages, indirects were awarded the largest share since January and dealers were left with the smallest portion since January.

* EUR: Last but not least in terms Thursday’s super Central Bank line up, as the ECB announced enhanced QE reinvestment guidance alongside unchanged key rates and confirmation that the APP will end after this month.  However, the devil was in the final 2018 presser where President Draghi revealed ongoing confidence about hitting the inflation target, but increasing caution surrounding the outlook, which translates to risks remaining balanced even though they are shifting towards the downside. The upshot, session lows for the single currency vs the Dollar and Pound, circa 1.1330 vs just above 1.1390 earlier in the news conference and almost 0.8950 vs 0.9015 respectively. Note, however, Eur/Usd did recover some lost ground into the NY cut when decent 1.5 bn option expiry interest between 1.1340-50 rolled off.

* DXY: Eur weakness prompted a broader Buck bounce and marginal new peaks for index just under 97.300 vs 96.871 at the other extreme, with perhaps some additional impetus from upbeat US weekly claims over significantly softer than expected import and export prices, and tech impulses as Fib support at 96.812 held, albeit just.

* AUD, NZD: The aforementioned Usd recovery sapped some strength from the Aud, but it still retained a firm grasp of the 0.7200 handle on improved US-China trade relations following the latter’s bulky soybean order and Beijing welcoming a Washington delegation. However, the Kiwi continued to lag and encircle the 0.6850 level after NZ’s semi-annual economic outlook overnight revised down projections.

* NOK, CHF, SEK: The Norwegian Krona and Swiss Franc were also eyeing end of year policy meeting and guidance for independent direction and the Nok initially rallied when the Norges Bank reaffirmed a likely next hike in March 2019, but gradually lost momentum on the longer term depo path profile that was trimmed to pencil a total of 2 rises next year, only 1 in 2020 vs 2 previously and another 2 the year after that. Eur/Nok back towards the middle of a 9.7080-9.7590 range. Conversely, the Chf remained relatively static as the SNB maintained a highly valued assessment of the currency and reiterated ‘fragile’ FX markets that warrant ongoing monitoring with intermittent action when needed, and no change in the NIRP. Back to Scandinavia, the Swedish Crown is actually ending the EU session ahead of the major pack with Eur/Sek back under 10.3000 as bearish/dovish vibes emanating from yesterday’s sub-consensus inflation data reversed on more upbeat Prospera price and Riksbank repo rate expectations.

* GBP, CAD, JPY: Mixed fortunes as the Pound retained an underlying bid on less unstable UK political grounds after PM May’s confidence vote victory, but pared best gains ahead of her pre-Summit with EU officials that appear willing to provide some assurances as long as the Brexit withdrawal draft is not altered materially. Cable is holding above 1.2650 s 1.2685 at best, while the Loonie has retreated from peaks vs its US peer to circa 1.3375 after a 2nd Canadian was arrested in China under suspicion of breaching national security. Similarly, the Jpy is testing a 113.61 fib after clearing big Japanese offers at 113.50 on the 2nd time of asking and pulled even further away from recent highs of 112.25.

EUR

Last but not least in terms Thursday’s super Central Bank line up, as the ECB announced enhanced QE reinvestment guidance alongside unchanged key rates and confirmation that the APP will end after this month.  However, the devil was in the final 2018 presser where President Draghi revealed ongoing confidence about hitting the inflation target, but increasing caution surrounding the outlook, which translates to risks remaining balanced even though they are shifting towards the downside. The upshot, session lows for the single currency vs the Dollar and Pound, circa 1.1330 vs just above 1.1390 earlier in the news conference and almost 0.8950 vs 0.9015 respectively. Note, however, Eur/Usd did recover some lost ground into the NY cut when decent 1.5 bn option expiry interest between 1.1340-50 rolled off.

DXY

Eur weakness prompted a broader Buck bounce and marginal new peaks for index just under 97.300 vs 96.871 at the other extreme, with perhaps some additional impetus from upbeat US weekly claims over significantly softer than expected import and export prices, and tech impulses as Fib support at 96.812 held, albeit just.

AUD/NZD

The aforementioned Usd recovery sapped some strength from the Aud, but it still retained a firm grasp of the 0.7200 handle on improved US-China trade relations following the latter’s bulky soybean order and Beijing welcoming a Washington delegation. However, the Kiwi continued to lag and encircle the 0.6850 level after NZ’s semi-annual economic outlook overnight revised down projections.

NOK/CHF/SEK

The Norwegian Krona and Swiss Franc were also eyeing end of year policy meeting and guidance for independent direction and the Nok initially rallied when the Norges Bank reaffirmed a likely next hike in March 2019, but gradually lost momentum on the longer term depo path profile that was trimmed to pencil a total of 2 rises next year, only 1 in 2020 vs 2 previously and another 2 the year after that. Eur/Nok back towards the middle of a 9.7080-9.7590 range. Conversely, the Chf remained relatively static as the SNB maintained a highly valued assessment of the currency and reiterated ‘fragile’ FX markets that warrant ongoing monitoring with intermittent action when needed, and no change in the NIRP. Back to Scandinavia, the Swedish Crown is actually ending the EU session ahead of the major pack with Eur/Sek back under 10.3000 as bearish/dovish vibes emanating from yesterday’s sub-consensus inflation data reversed on more upbeat Prospera price and Riksbank repo rate expectations.

GBP/CAD/JPY   

Mixed fortunes as the Pound retained an underlying bid on less unstable UK political grounds after PM May’s confidence vote victory, but pared best gains ahead of her pre-Summit with EU officials that appear willing to provide some assurances as long as the Brexit withdrawal draft is not altered materially. Cable is holding above 1.2600 vs 1.2685 at best, while the Loonie has retreated from peaks vs its US peer to circa 1.3375 after a 2nd Canadian was arrested in China under suspicion of breaching national security. Similarly, the Jpy is testing a 113.61 fib after clearing big Japanese offers at 113.50 on the 2nd time of asking and pulled even further away from recent highs of 112.25.

Elsewhere, publishers are reportedly “wary” of joining Apple’s new “Netflix for magazines” platform, called Texture, over fears of a fall in revenue. subject: ECB statement confirms asset purchases will conclude at the end of 2018, enhances forward guidance on reinvestments
content:
• KEY RATES: ECB keeps all key rates on hold, as expected
  • RATE GUIDANCE: Reiterates rates to remain at their present levels at least through the summer of 2019
  • ASSET PURCHASES: ECB confirms asset purchases will conclude at the end of 2018, as planned
  • REINVESTMENT GUIDANCE: Governing Council is enhancing its forward guidance on reinvestment. Accordingly, the Governing Council intends to continue reinvesting, in full, the principal payments from maturing securities purchased under the APP for an extended period of time past the date when it starts raising the key ECB interest rates, and in any case for as long as necessary to maintain favourable liquidity conditions and an ample degree of monetary accommodation.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 13th December 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Major European Indices are mixed, as markets await the latest ECB policy announcement
  • Sterling the major G10 outperformer in the aftermath of PM May’s confidence vote victory last night
  • ECB Interest Rate Decision, US Import and Export Prices, US 30yr Bond Auction

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded positively as the region followed suit to the gains on Wall St amid trade-related hopes after news of further potential concessions by China. As such, ASX 200 (+0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.0%) were higher but with gains in Australia capped by losses in the telecoms sector after the competition regulator expressed preliminary concerns regarding proposed TPG Telecom - Vodafone Hutchison Australia merger which resulted to a near-17% drop in TPG shares, while property-related weakness also restricted upside. Hang Seng (+1.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.4%) were lifted amid the encouraging trade-related developments with China preparing to increase access for overseas companies and is working to replace its Made in China 2025 plan with one that tones down its bid to dominate manufacturing, while Chinese importers have also resumed purchases of US soybeans and are said to purchase as much as 2mln tons of US soybeans vs. earlier reports of 500k tons. Finally, 10yr JGBs traded lacklustre amid gains in stocks and similar subdued price action in T-notes, with a mixed 5yr auction result adding to the drab mood.

PBoC skipped open market operations. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8769 (Prev. 6.9064)

China was said to purchase as much as 2mln tons of US soybeans vs. earlier reports of 500k tons. (Newswires)

Canadian Foreign Minister Freeland said a 2nd Canadian citizen may have been detained in China, while reports later noted that Canadian Michael Spavor is under investigation in China on suspicion of harming national security. (Globe and Mail/Newswires)

TRADE

Chinese Commerce Ministry announce that they welcome a US trade delegation to visit China. (Newswires)

UK/EU/US

Draft EU document prepared for PM May is said to include possibility the EU are to look into giving more backstop assurances according to EU diplomatic sources. However, there were also reports that EU is poised to reject UK PM May's demands for legally binding assurances that the backstop will only be temporary and that EU leaders are to only give PM May 10 minutes of their time. (Newswires/Telegraph)

UK RICS House Price Balance (Nov) -11% vs. Exp. -10% (Prev. -10%). RICS Chief Economist said it is evident that Brexit uncertainties are taking toll on UK property market, while it was also noted that the time taken to complete home sales was longest since series was introduced in February last year. (Newswires)

Discussions between the DUP and Labour to find “common ground” are taking place “at a senior level” as Labour mulls triggering a no-confidence motion in the government before Christmas, according to the Huffington Post. (Newswires)

Brexit Minister Barclay states that the UK will have safeguards about coming out of the backstop, adding that both sides see the backstop as being temporary. (Newswires)

German Conservative Foreign Policy spokesman says that the EU has worked on creative solutions for Brexit, there is nothing left that we can do all possibilities have been exhausted. (Newswires)

No UK meaningful vote on PM May's deal is scheduled before Christmas; according to Parliament Leader Leadsom. (Newswires)

Former UK Brexit Secretary Raab says it looks very difficult to see how PM May can lead the UK forward; according to BBC's Political Editor Kuenssberg. (Newswires)

Michael Cohen’s lawyer said US President Trump and White House knew Cohen would give false testimony in Congress and did not tell him not to. (Newswires)

US Rep. Meadows is said to be out of running for White House Chief of Staff role. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

Swiss 3M Target LIBOR Rate Q4 -0.75% vs. Exp. -0.75% (Prev. -0.75%), LIBOR Corridor (Q4) -1.25--0.25% vs. Exp. -1.25--0.25% (Prev. -1.25--0.25%)

- The SNB says that the CHF is highly valued, situation on FX market is still fragile

- The SNB says that they will remain active in FX markets as necessary, while taken overall currency situation into consideration

- The SNB sees 2018 inflation at 0.9% vs. prev. 0.9%, 2019 at 0.5% (vs. prev. 0.8%), 2020 1.0% (vs. prev. 1.2%)                                -  See 2018 growth at around 2.5% (vs. prev. 2.0-2.5%), sees 2019 growth at around 1.5%. (Newswires)

SNB's Chairman Jordan says the SNB sees risk of major and sudden exchange rate movements which would significantly alter monetary conditions. (Newswires)

Norwegian Key Policy Rate 0.75% vs. Exp. 0.75% (Prev. 0.75%)

- Current assessment of the outlook and balance of risks suggests the rate will most likely be raised in March 2019.

- Norges Bank sees 2019 key policy rate at 1.0% vs. Prev forecast of 1.0%.

- Norges Bank sees 2019 core CPI at 2.0% vs. Prev forecast of 1.7%, and 2020 core CPI at 1.9% vs. Prev. forecast of 1.6%.

- Norges Bank sees 2019 non-oil GDP growth at 2.3% vs. Prev forecast of 2.5%

Norges Bank Governor Olsen says he sees gradual rate hikes in years to come, two rate hikes in 2019, one in 2020 and two in 2021, additionally says that oil price decline means slower wage growth. (Newswires)

Turkish CBT Weekly Repo Rate Dec 24.0% vs. Exp. 24.0% (Prev. 24.0%)

- CBRT say that further monetary tightening will be delivered if needed, and will use all instruments available to pursue price  stability objective

- Decided to maintain a tight monetary policy stance until inflation outlook displays a significant improvement

EQUITIES

Major European Indices are mixed with the FTSE MIB (+1.0%) outperforming due to the indices banks outperforming on Italian PM Conte stating the nations deficit goal is now 2.04%; while the EC comments that good progress has been made on this. FTSE 100 (U/C) is trading flat, with Associated British Foods (-0.6%) and 3I group (-2.1%) trading ex-dividends towards the bottom of the index.  At the top of the index are TUI (+5.0%) expecting 10% underlying earnings growth at constant currencies for 2019. In terms of other notable movers G4S (+9.0%) are reviewing separation options for their cash solution business and Sainsbury’s (+1.3%) are up as they are challenging a refusal for additional time by the regulator regarding their merger with Asda. Sectors are broadly in the red with some underperformance seen in Energy while Utilities are the outperforming sector.

FX

GBP, EUR – Sterling the major G10 outperformer in the aftermath of PM May’s confidence vote victory last night, with some support also provided by the a draft document including the possibility that the EU are to look into giving more backstop assurances. As such cable remains firmly above 1.2600, albeit off highs of 1.2685 with large options around 1.2650-60 (1.2bln) perhaps hampering further attempts towards 1.2700. Meanwhile, the EUR also feels some benefit from the softer dollar, but is lagging vs. the Pound as EUR/GBP slips below 0.9000 ahead of the ECB policy decision. Note: please refer to the research suite for a full preview.

NOK, CHF – Staying with the Central Bank theme, two out of the four end of year meetings have already passed and the Norwegian Crown strengthened in light of the Norges Bank’s current assessment reaffirming that rates will “most likely” be raised in March 2019. This, alongside upgrades to core CPI pulled EUR/NOK to lows of 9.7071 (vs. high of 9.7531).

Conversely, the CHF was largely docile in wake of the SNB keeping its key rate and corridor unchanged, as expected. The Swiss Central Bank also maintained that the Franc is “highly valued” alongside reiterating its preparedness to intervene if required and utilise the balance sheet to react in the event of shocks. Note, SNB Head Jordan stressed the risk of major and sudden exchange rate movements which would significantly alter monetary conditions. As such EUR/CHF remains within a the bottom of a 1.1301-1.1281 range.

AUD, NZD – The high-beta currencies continue to prosper in the more positive US-China trade environment, with the with AUD/USD building on gains above 0.7200 to just shy of 0.7250 at one stage, but also wary of big option interest at 0.7200 (1.3bln). Meanwhile NZD/USD remains sub-0.6900, albeit near the top of a 0.6880-42 range despite the downward revisions in the New Zealand HY economic and fiscal updates.

JPY – Rangebound trade for the Yen ahead of tonight’s Tankan Survey release with USD/JPY hovering sub-113.50 (with resistance around the figure). In terms of technical, a key fib level sits at 113.61, with 750mln between 113.60-65. In terms of noteworthy option expiries to the downside, 113.00-10 (1.1bln) and 113.30-40 (1bln)

TRY – Back to Central Banks, CBRT left its key one-week repo on hold as widely expected and maintained a tightened bias until the inflation outlook displays a significant improvement, though the Bank did acknowledge the recent sub-forecast CPI release, along with import prices and domestic demand condition. As such USD/TRY fell to lows just shy of 5.3000 vs. highs of 5.3837

FIXED INCOME

The confidence motion driven bearish start for Gilts on the open has gradually been eliminated, with the 10-year future printing fresh session highs of 123.69 as focus returns to the difficulty of getting a cabinet-acceptable Brexit deal, with the EU reiterating their “non-negotiable” stance ahead of the EU summit today and tomorrow. Bunds have also bounced off lows to test chart resistance at 162.92 and settling above the technical level of 162.82 as risk sentiment turns marginally negative. This comes as the IFO downwardly revised their German growth forecasts, alongside ECB sources stating inflation and growth forecasts are set to be revised at the upcoming meeting today. This is seeing extended rotation into the periphery, with BTPs outperforming their counterparts (trading around highs above 126.00 vs. 126.14 at best) as Italy’s 2.04% deficit/GDP target is being received positively by the EU. OATs are also benefitting from the EU’s reassertion that France’s budget is not set to be analysed until the new year. Further, upside in both France and Italy is being aided by Citi’s European Government Bond Index year-end re-weighting, that has also seen an extension of 0.03 years.

US 10-year futures are following suit with the benchmark trading around the 120-10 handle and awaiting direction ahead of US jobless claims and USD 16bln 30yr issuance later in the day.

COMMODITIES 

Brent (-0.3%) and WTI (-0.4%) are down on the session in a continuation of yesterday's price action. In terms of recent newsflow, the latest IEA’s monthly report saw the agency cut non-OPEC oil supply growth forecasts by 415,000 BPD to 1.5mln BPD vs. 2.4mln BPD in 2018. The IEA also left global oil demand growth unchanged at 1.3mln BPD and 1.4mln BPD for 2018 and 2019 respectively. This follows yesterday’s monthly OPEC report where demand estimates were left unchanged. Whereas, non-OPEC oil supply in 2018 is forecast to grow by 2.5mln BPD, which was an upward revision of 190k BPD; with this in mind, some suggest that OPEC will need to make further cuts over the second half of 2019.

Gold is trading flat within a slim USD 2/oz range, as the dollar steadies with the DXY unchanged on the day. Base metals continue to see support after yesterday's news that China are preparing to increase access for overseas companies with sentiment also bolstered this morning after the Chinese Commerce Ministry stated that they would welcome a US trade delegation visit. Copper prices have hit a 1-week high on these trade developments. Separately, steel prices have risen on a potential boost to demand arising from expectations that China are to launch more infrastructure products next year.

IEA Monthly Report: global oil demand growth for 2018 and 2019 maintained at 1.3mln BPD and 1.4mln BPD respectively. Cut non-OPEC oil supply growth forecasts by 415,000 BPD to 1.5mln BPD vs. 2.4mln BPD in 2018, and see global oil market moving into deficit by Q2 2019 assuming 100% OPEC compliance with the supply deal.

subject: PBoC Governor Gang says China's economic growth has neared potential rate, overcapacity has eased significantly, but downward pressure on China's economy is increasing,
content: • He adds China will flexibly adjust monetary policy based on economic changes and says money supply, total social financing growth are appropriate for economic growth

subject: UK debt and STIR futures acknowledge PM May’s survival to a degree
content: In keeping with the relatively tame response in FX, before the more recent uptick in Cable and decline through 0.900 in Eur/Gbp, Gilts resumed only a modest 19 ticks down from yesterday’s 123.38 Liffe close and dipped to 123.12 prior to a bounce that has seen losses cut to just 1 solitary tick. Meanwhile, 3 month contracts have also found an early base after declining up to 3 ticks, awaiting the next Brexit developments and efforts by PM May to obtain the assurances from the EU required for UK parliament ratification. On that note, her leadership ballot win could be deemed hollow or merely a stay of execution as she still faces significant opposition within the Conservative Party and Whitehall, let alone a resolute stance from Brussels on the issues of a back-stop time limit and option to exit the arrangement if it is enacted.

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 13th December 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets traded positively as the region followed suit from the gains on Wall St amid trade-related hopes after news of further potential concessions by China
  • UK PM May survived the confidence vote in which 200 voted that they have confidence vs. 117 for no confidence
  • Looking ahead, highlights include SNB, Norges, ECB and CBRT Interest Rate Decisions, German CPI (F), US Import and Export Prices, US 30yr Bond Auction

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded positively as the region followed suit from the gains on Wall St amid trade-related hopes after news of further potential concessions by China. As such, ASX 200 (+0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.0%) were higher but with gains in Australia capped by losses in the telecoms sector after the competition regulator expressed preliminary concerns regarding proposed TPG Telecom - Vodafone Hutchison Australia merger which resulted to a near-17% drop in TPG shares, while property-related weakness also restricted upside. Hang Seng (+1.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.4%) were lifted amid the encouraging trade-related developments with China preparing to increase access for overseas companies and is working to replace its Made in China 2025 plan with one that tones down its bid to dominate manufacturing, while Chinese importers have also resumed purchases of US soybeans and are said to purchase as much as 2mln tons of US soybeans vs. earlier reports of 500k tons. Finally, 10yr JGBs traded lacklustre amid gains in stocks and similar subdued price action in T-notes, with a mixed 5yr auction result adding to the drab mood.

PBoC skipped open market operations. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8769 (Prev. 6.9064)

China was said to purchase as much as 2mln tons of US soybeans vs. earlier reports of 500k tons. (Newswires)

Canadian Foreign Minister Freeland said a 2nd Canadian citizen may have been detained in China, while reports later noted that Canadian Michael Spavor is under investigation in China on suspicion of harming national security. (Globe and Mail/Newswires)


UK/EU

UK PM May survived the confidence vote in which 200 voted that they have confidence vs. 117 for no confidence, while she commented after that it is time to get on with the Brexit process and that she will be seeking more assurances on the backstop when she visits the EU Council today. (Newswires)

Draft EU document prepared for PM May is said to include possibility the EU are to look into giving more backstop assurances according to EU diplomatic sources. However, there were also reports that EU is poised to reject UK PM May's demands for legally binding assurances that the backstop will only be temporary and that EU leaders are to only give PM May 10 minutes of their time. (Newswires/Telegraph)

UK RICS House Price Balance (Nov) -11% vs. Exp. -10% (Prev. -10%). RICS Chief Economist said it is evident that Brexit uncertainties are taking toll on UK property market, while it was also noted that the time taken to complete home sales was longest since series was introduced in February last year. (Newswires)


Italy PM Conte said proposals to tweak next year's budget don't betray promises to Italians and that deficit goal is now 2.04% of GDP, while there were also comments from European Commission spokesperson that Italy have made good progress on the 2019 budget. (Newswires)

FX

FX markets quietened overnight in which the DXY traded sideways and just about stayed above the 97.00 level following the prior day’s broad softness, which has helped its major counterparts hold on to most their recent gains with EUR/USD biding its time ahead of today’s ECB policy meeting and with GBP/USD kept afloat after PM May’s confidence vote survival. Elsewhere, USD/JPY was underpinned by the risk appetite and antipodeans were mixed as AUD benefitted from the risk tone as well as its heavy exposure to China, while NZD remained subdued after downward revisions in New Zealand’s Half Year Economic and Fiscal Update.


COMMODITIES

Commodities traded mixed in which WTI crude futures languished following the prior day’s late pressure as prices took out support at USD 52.00/bbl amid broad weakness in the energy complex, which followed on from the DoE report. Elsewhere, gold was flat as support from a subdued greenback was counterbalanced by lack of demand for safe-havens, while copper gains extended on gains amid the risk appetite and outperformance in its largest consumer China.

US


Positive risk sentiment pressured the complex on Wednesday which remained in negative territory; in early US trade, selling action extended after WSJ reports suggested that China are looking to boost access to oversee countries. The complex pared back some losses after the 10-year auction which was soft overall. Most of the action was concentrated in the front end and belly of the curve where yields were higher by c.3bps at settlement. Spreads were mixed but mostly steeper heading into the close. The US treasury sold USD 24bln of 10-year tailing by 0.5bps at a high yield 2.915%. Demand for the auction was below recent averages as indicated by the bid-to-cover which was the lowest since February. Indirects were awarded the smallest share since August, directs took the largest portion since September and dealers were left with a share close to recent averages. US T-note futures (Z8) settled 5+ tick lower at 120-09.

Michael Cohen lawyer said US President Trump and White House knew Cohen would give false testimony in Congress and did not tell him not to. (Newswires)

US Rep. Meadows is said to be out of running for White House Chief of Staff role. (Newswires)
